imageAlt: Anterior view of the human face with sinuses highlighted.
stem: The nurse palpates the sinuses for tenderness. Click on the location of the Frontal Sinuses.

rationale.correct: The frontal sinuses are located in the frontal bone above and medial to the orbits (under the eyebrows). Tenderness here suggests frontal sinusitis.
rationale.incorrect: The maxillary sinuses (h2) are located in the cheek area below the eyes. The ethmoid sinuses (h3) are located deeper behind the bridge of the nose.
clinicalPearls: Palpate the frontal and maxillary sinuses to assess for acute sinusitis.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: The frontal sinuses are specifically in the forehead; the ethmoid sinuses are found at the bridge of the nose.

reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with assessment. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

imageAlt: Lateral view of the neck showing lymph node chains.
stem: A client has Pharyngitis (Strep Throat). Click on the lymph node chain most likely to be enlarged and tender (Anterior Cervical).

rationale.correct: The anterior cervical nodes, located anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, drain the throat and pharynx and are frequently tender in pharyngitis.
rationale.incorrect: Supraclavicular nodes (h2) drain the thoracic cavity and abdomen; enlargement here is often associated with malignancy (Virchow's node). Occipital nodes (h3) drain the scalp.
clinicalPearls: Enlarged, tender nodes usually signify infection; non-tender, hard, fixed nodes suggest malignancy.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Painful nodes almost always signify infection; hard, painless, fixed nodes are highly suspicious for malignancy.

stem: A client presents with gnawing, burning pain that radiates to the back. Click on the Epigastric Region.

rationale.correct: The Epigastric region is located superior to the umbilical region and inferior to the xiphoid process. Pain here is classic for Peptic Ulcer Disease or Pancreatitis.
rationale.incorrect: The Umbilical region (h2) is the center portion. The Hypogastric/Suprapubic region (h3) is the lower middle portion.
clinicalPearls: Epigastric pain radiating to the back is a hallmark sign of acute pancreatitis.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Epigastric pain can occasionally be the primary symptom of an inferior wall MI; always screen for cardiac history.

stem: The nurse palpates for a distended bladder. Click on the Suprapubic (Hypogastric) Region.

rationale.correct: The bladder is located in the Suprapubic (hypogastric) region. When distended, it can be palpated as a firm, rounded mass above the symphysis pubis.
rationale.incorrect: The Right Iliac (h2) contains the appendix. The Left Iliac (h3) contains the sigmoid colon.
clinicalPearls: A distended bladder can cause restlessness and increased blood pressure in unconscious or non-verbal patients.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: The bladder is a midline structure (Suprapubic); the appendix is found in the Right Iliac region.

imageAlt: Anterior view of the arm showing veins.
stem: The nurse needs to insert a large-bore IV for fluid resuscitation in an emergency. Click on the Antecubital Fossa site.

rationale.correct: The large veins (Cephalic/Basilic) in the Antecubital (AC) fossa are the preferred sites in emergencies because they are large and accessible, allowing for rapid fluid infusion.
rationale.incorrect: Veins in the hand/wrist (h2) are smaller and more prone to infiltration/occlusion during resuscitation. The upper arm (h3) has deeper veins that are harder to access without ultrasound.
clinicalPearls: Use an 18-gauge or larger needle for rapid fluid resuscitation or blood products.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: IVs in the AC fossa (elbow) often occlude when the patient bends their arm; consider an arm board or alternate site if mobility is needed.

imageAlt: Anterior view of the wrist showing palpable pulses.
stem: The nurse prepares to perform an Allen Test before an ABG draw. Click on the Radial Artery.

rationale.correct: The Radial Artery is located on the lateral (thumb) side of the wrist. It is the most common site for ABG sampling due to its accessibility.
rationale.incorrect: The Ulnar Artery (h2) is on the medial (pinky) side. The mid-forearm (h3) does not have easily palpable surface arteries.
clinicalPearls: The Allen test must be performed to ensure ulnar collateral circulation before radial puncture.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: We test the ulnar artery for backing up circulation, but we perform the stick on the Radial artery.

mnemonic.title: R-R-R
mnemonic.expansion: Radial = Right on the thumb side.

reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with procedures. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: The nurse administers a Vitamin K injection to a newborn. Click on the Vastus Lateralis muscle.

rationale.correct: The Vastus Lateralis muscle (lateral thigh) is the preferred IM site for newborns and infants because it is the most developed muscle at birth and lacks major nerves/vessels.
rationale.incorrect: The inner thigh (h2) contains the femoral artery/vein and is unsafe. The hip (h3)/gluteal muscles are underdeveloped until the child has been walking for at least a year.
clinicalPearls: Vitamin K is given to newborns to prevent Vitamin K Deficiency Bleeding (VKDB) since their gut is sterile at birth.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never use gluteal sites in infants; they lack the muscle mass to safely absorb the medication without nerve risk.

imageAlt: Open mouth with tongue lifted to roof of mouth.
stem: The nurse instructs a client to take Nitroglycerin for angina. Click on the area where the pill should be placed.

rationale.correct: Sublingual (SL) medications are placed under the tongue. The rich blood supply allows the medication to be absorbed directly into the systemic circulation, bypassing the first-pass metabolism of the liver.
rationale.incorrect: Placed on top of the tongue (h2), the medication would be swallowed and inactivated by stomach acid. The cheek pouch (h3) is for buccal administration.
clinicalPearls: Instruct the patient not to swallow the SL tablet or drink water until it is fully dissolved.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Do not allow the patient to drink fluids until the sublingual tablet is 100% dissolved.

stem: The provider orders a buccal medication. Click on the correct administration site.

rationale.correct: Buccal administration involves placing the medication between the cheek and the gum (buccal pocket). It is absorbed through the oral mucosa.
rationale.incorrect: Under the tongue (h2) is for sublingual administration. Swallowing (h3) is for oral (PO) medications.
clinicalPearls: Alternate cheeks with subsequent doses to prevent mucosal irritation.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: The patient must not swallow the buccal medication; it is designed to dissolve and absorb through the mucosa.

mnemonic.title: B-B
mnemonic.expansion: Buccal = Bite of the cheek pocket.

imageAlt: Close up of an eye being held open.
stem: The nurse administers eye drops. Click on the correct location to instill the drop.

rationale.correct: Instill eye drops into the lower conjunctival sac. This provides an even distribution of the medication across the eye and reduces the risk of corneal injury.
rationale.incorrect: Instilling drops directly onto the cornea (h2) is painful and can cause damage. The inner canthus (h3) is where the medication drains; pressure should be applied here AFTER instillation to prevent systemic absorption.
clinicalPearls: Instruct the patient to look up while instilling drops.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Avoid dropping directly on the pupil or cornea as it causes immediate pain and reflexive blinking.

imageAlt: View from behind a patient's neck.
stem: The nurse palpates the thyroid gland from the posterior approach. Click on the location of the thyroid isthmus.

rationale.correct: The thyroid isthmus is located just below the cricoid cartilage in the midline of the neck, connecting the two lobes.
rationale.incorrect: The Thyroid Cartilage (h2) is the prominent 'Adam's Apple' which is superior to the thyroid gland. The SCM muscle (h3) is a landmark but not part of the gland itself.
clinicalPearls: Ask the patient to swallow while palpating; the thyroid moves up with the trachea.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't go too high; the thyroid gland sits inferior to the prominent thyroid cartilage (Adam's apple).

stem: To perform the Allen Test, the nurse must compress the Radial and which other artery simultaneously? Click its location.

rationale.correct: The Allen test requires compressing the Ulnar Artery (medial side) along with the Radial Artery to assess collateral circulation to the hand.
rationale.incorrect: The Radial Artery (h2) is already mentioned in the stem. The Median Nerve (h3) is not an artery and should not be compressed for this test.
clinicalPearls: The hand should 'flush' or turn pink within 5-15 seconds after releasing the ulnar artery if circulation is adequate.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the hand takes longer than 15 seconds to flush, the test is failed; the radial artery should not be used.

imageAlt: Cross section of skin and muscle tissue layers.
stem: The nurse uses the Z-track method for an IM injection. Click on the tissue layer where the medication is deposited.

rationale.correct: IM injections are deposited into the deep muscle layer (h1). The Z-track technique displaces the skin and subcutaneous tissue during injection to seal the medication in the muscle.
rationale.incorrect: The Subcutaneous tissue (h2) is for SC injections (e.g., Insulin). The Epidermis (h3) is for intradermal injections (e.g., PPD).
clinicalPearls: Z-track prevents skin staining and irritation from medications like parenteral iron.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never massage a Z-track site; it can force the irritating medication back into the upper skin layers.

imageAlt: Lateral view of the outer ear (pinna).
stem: The nurse administers otic drops to an adult. Click on the part of the ear the nurse pulls to straighten the canal.

rationale.correct: For adults and children >3 years, pull the pinna (helix) UP and BACK to straighten the auditory canal.
rationale.incorrect: Pulling the lobe down and back (h2) is only for infants and children <3 years old. The tragus (h3) should be pressed lightly after drops are instilled to help them reach the eardrum.
clinicalPearls: Avoid cold ear drops; they can trigger acute dizziness or pain.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: The cutoff is 3 years of age. Over 3 = Pull UP. Under 3 = Pull DOWN.
